metadata.titleEn: Ground observation dataset of corn biomass, vegetation coverage, leaf area index and plant height at Daman station in the middle reaches of Heihe River (growth period in 2018)
metadata.description: This dataset is a continuous ground observation data of vegetation coverage (%), biomass (g/plant), leaf area index (LAI) and plant height (cm) of field corn during the growing period in 2018 at Daman Station ( 38.85551N,100.37223E)in the middle reaches of the Heihe River. Ground observation was carried out in three sample plots.  Biomass observation included fresh and dry aboveground biomass, fresh and dry underground biomass (fresh and dry root weight), vegetation coverage was observed by digital camera, leaf area index was observed by LAI 2200, and plant height was observed by tape measure. The observation period was from May 26 to September 26, 2018, in which LAI started from May 30. Observation parameters were observed every 5 days before July 31 and every 10 days thereafter, and a total of 22 observations (LAI was 20) were carried out during the whole growing period. The dataset can provide data basis for inversion and validation of surface vegetation parameters.
metadata.instructions: Observation data are stored in Excel form. The file name is yyyy.xlsm, where yyyy stands for year.

background: Crop biomass is one of the most important biophysical indicators of crop growth. The accurate and efficient estimation of the regional crop biomass at different growth stages is of great importance in guiding crop management decision making, such as in effective fertilization, water irrigation, weeding, and pest and disease management. In addition, as an important aspect of biomass energy, the accurate estimation of crop biomass contributes to the rational and effective utilization of biomass energy. Moreover, effective estimates of crop biomass during the growing season could play a key role in crop yield prediction. The traditional crop biomass estimation method is mainly based on field measurements, which include destructive field sampling, laboratory drying and weighting. The traditional methods are relatively accurate, but they are labor intensive and time consuming. Moreover, the sparse nature of space makes it impossible to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales. Thus, it is impossible to acquire the regional crop biomass via ground measurements alone. The satellite remote sensing technique is a unique and useful method for crop biomass monitoring in a repeatable manner due to the valuable information it provides on vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage and long time series, which effectively compensates for the deficiency of traditional biomass estimation methods. Previous studies have revealed that remote sensing is a reliable and effective technique to obtain biophysical and biochemical crop information.
research objective: In this paper, four machine learning models, namely random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), artificial neural network (ANN), and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) were adopted to estimate the seasonal corn biomass based on field observation data and moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) reflectance data from 2012 to 2019 in the middle reaches of the Heihe River basin, China.
challenges: This is currently one of the major challenges for agricultural researchers and farm managers.
methods: In this study, the corn biomass was estimated based on daily MODIS datasets with a 500 m spatial resolution combined with long-term ground observation data in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin, and four machine learning algorithms, namely RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost, were adopted to predict the biomass. Large, relatively homogeneous areas, which mainly functioned as corn growing areas, were selected as the sample sites. According to a field survey of the sample sites, a total of sixteen sites were selected in 2012, and three sites were selected for field measurement purposes every year from 2013 to 2019. One to three plots for each sample site were chosen for further biomass observation, with each plot covering an area of 100 m ×100 m. All selected plants in each plot were collected, and the roots of the corn plants were washed. The fresh weight was measured, after which the plants were transported to the laboratory, chopped into easy-to-dry segments, and dried in an oven at 85°C for 48–72 h until a constant dry biomass was obtained. MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products from May to September from 2012 to 2019 were analyzed in this study. The forward feature selection method was implemented to choose the most influential variables, which is an iterative method starting from the condition of no model features. In each iteration, we add a given feature that best improves the model until the addition of a new variable does not further improve the model performance. The RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost algorithms were adopted in this study. R software was used to implement the above four machine learning algorithms with the randomForest, kernlab, brnn, and xgboost packages. In this study, the caret package in R software was applied to tune the parameters of the above four machine learning algorithms. The 10-fold cross validation method was implemented to evaluate the performance of the above four machine learning models due to the small number of training samples.
dataset: MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products from May to September from 2012 to 2019 were analyzed in this study. A total of sixteen sites were selected in 2012, and three sites were selected for field measurement purposes every year from 2013 to 2019. One to three plots for each sample site were chosen for further biomass observation, with each plot covering an area of 100 m ×100 m.
findings: The results indicated that the corn biomass was suitably estimated (the coefficient of determination (R2) was between 0.72 and 0.78) with the four machine learning models. The XGBoost model performed better than the other three models (R2 = 0.78, root mean squared error (RMSE) = 2.86 t/ha and mean absolute error (MAE) = 1.86 t/ha). Moreover, the RF model was an effective method (R2 = 0.77, RMSE = 2.91 t/ha and MAE = 1.91 t/ha), with a performance comparable to that of the XGBoost model.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in accurately estimating regional crop biomass using traditional methods?
Example.Answer: A challenge in accurately estimating regional crop biomass using traditional methods is that they are labor-intensive and time-consuming. These methods involve destructive field sampling, laboratory drying, and weighing. Additionally, their sparse nature makes it impossible to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales, necessitating the use of satellite remote sensing techniques as a complementary approach.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that could be used to estimate corn biomass in a specific geographical area over a period of time?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used to estimate corn biomass is the MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products from May to September from 2012 to 2019. These datasets were analyzed to estimate corn biomass in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin, China, using machine learning algorithms combined with ground observation data.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the properties of satellite remote sensing datasets that make them suitable for regional crop biomass estimation?
Feature Specification.Answer: high spatial coverage, long time series, ability to provide information on vegetation parameters, repeatable method for monitoring, extraction of biophysical and biochemical crop information

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'vegetation coverage percentage' in the context of ground observation data collection for crop biomass estimation?
Definition.Answer: Vegetation coverage percentage refers to the proportion of ground area covered by vegetation as observed from the ground. It is typically measured using digital photography methods to capture the extent of plant coverage over a given area.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques of ground-based measurements compare to satellite remote sensing methods in estimating crop biomass in terms of labor intensity and spatial coverage?
Comparison.Answer: Ground-based measurements, such as destructive field sampling and laboratory drying, are accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming, with limitations in spatial coverage. In contrast, satellite remote sensing offers repeatable monitoring with high spatial coverage and long time series, compensating for the deficiencies of traditional methods by providing regional or larger scale data.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in data collection frequency and temporal resolution between the ground observation dataset and the MODIS remote sensing dataset for corn biomass estimation?
Comparison.Answer: The ground observation dataset collected data frequently during the crop growing season, initially every five days and later every ten days, resulting in 22 observations. MODIS datasets, on the other hand, provided daily data with a 500 m spatial resolution over several years (2012-2019), allowing for consistent long-term monitoring but with less frequent direct interaction compared to ground methods.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do machine learning models like RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost differ in their application to crop biomass estimation when using ground and satellite data?
Comparison.Answer: Machine learning models such as RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost are applied to integrate ground and MODIS satellite data to predict crop biomass. XGBoost outperformed other models with an R2 of 0.78, indicating its effectiveness in handling the combined data types. RF also showed comparable performance, highlighting differences in how each algorithm processes and utilizes data for biomass estimation.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying principles can be inferred from the use of both ground observation and satellite remote sensing for estimating crop biomass?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of both ground observation and satellite remote sensing suggests a complementary data collection strategy that combines the detailed, accurate features of ground data with the extensive spatial and temporal coverage provided by satellite data. This approach reflects an understanding that integrating these methods can overcome the limitations of each when used alone, such as the labor-intensive nature of ground observations and the broad but sometimes less precise data from satellites.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the necessity of using both ground observations and satellite remote sensing data for estimating crop biomass in agricultural research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Ground observations provide accurate and detailed information on parameters like biomass, but are limited by labor intensity, time consumption, and spatial coverage. Satellite remote sensing complements this by offering repeatable, high spatial coverage and long time series data, effectively compensating for the limitations of traditional methods and enabling regional scale biomass monitoring.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the implications of using traditional field measurement methods for crop biomass estimation compared to employing satellite remote sensing techniques?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The implications of using traditional field measurement methods are that while they may provide accurate results, they are labor-intensive and time-consuming. Additionally, they cannot provide comprehensive regional or large-scale data. In contrast, satellite remote sensing techniques offer repeatable monitoring with high spatial coverage and long time series, effectively compensating for the deficiencies of traditional methods.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the expected consequences of implementing the forward feature selection method when choosing variables for machine learning models in crop biomass estimation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing the forward feature selection method is expected to enhance the performance of machine learning models by iteratively adding features that best improve the model until no further improvement is achieved. This method helps in selecting the most influential variables, thereby optimizing the models for more accurate crop biomass estimation.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intention behind employing both traditional field measurements and remote sensing techniques for corn biomass estimation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to leverage the high spatial coverage and long time series information provided by satellite remote sensing to overcome the limitations of traditional field measurements, which are accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming. By integrating these methods, researchers aim to improve the estimation of crop biomass at regional scales, facilitating better crop management and biomass energy utilization.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to integrate machine learning models with MODIS reflectance data for estimating seasonal corn biomass?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration of machine learning models with MODIS reflectance data aims to enhance the accuracy and efficiency of corn biomass estimation over large areas. This approach allows researchers to utilize valuable vegetation parameter data from remote sensing, providing a more comprehensive understanding of biomass distribution and supporting effective decision-making for crop management.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of conducting ground observation data collection at specific sample sites for biomass estimation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose of collecting ground observation data at specific sample sites is to provide a reliable basis for validating and calibrating remote sensing data and machine learning models. These ground measurements help ensure that the estimates of biomass are accurate and reflective of actual conditions, thus supporting more effective crop yield predictions and biomass energy assessments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can digital photography and specific instruments be utilized to assess vegetation parameters like canopy cover and leaf area index in agricultural fields?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Vegetation parameters such as canopy cover are assessed using digital photography methods, while leaf area index is measured using the LAI 2200 instrument. Observations are conducted at regular intervals over the growing season to provide continuous monitoring of these parameters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in the iterative process of selecting influential variables for crop biomass prediction models?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The forward feature selection method is used, starting with no model features. In each iteration, a given feature that best improves model performance is added until no further improvement is observed. This process helps refine machine learning models by selecting the most influential variables for accurate biomass prediction.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the accurate and efficient estimation of crop biomass at different growth stages in large-scale agricultural areas?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of satellite remote sensing techniques with machine learning models such as RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost enables the accurate and efficient estimation of crop biomass by providing valuable information on vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage, and long time series data, effectively compensating for the limitations of traditional biomass estimation methods.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of digital imaging and LAI measurements enable the collection of detailed vegetation parameters during the growing season?
Enablement.Answer: Digital imaging using a camera for vegetation coverage and the LAI 2200 instrument for leaf area index measurements enable the collection of detailed vegetation parameters by providing continuous ground observation data, which offer a foundation for surface vegetation parameter inversion and validation.

Enablement.Question: What factors facilitate the implementation of machine learning algorithms in estimating crop biomass using satellite data?
Enablement.Answer: The use of daily MODIS datasets with a 500 m spatial resolution combined with long-term ground observation data facilitates the implementation of machine learning algorithms like RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost in estimating crop biomass by selecting large, relatively homogeneous sample sites and employing iterative forward feature selection to identify influential variables.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional field measurement methods be insufficient for estimating crop biomass at a regional scale?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional methods are labor-intensive, time-consuming, and cannot provide comprehensive regional or larger scale estimates due to their sparse nature. Satellite remote sensing techniques offer valuable information on vegetation parameters with high spatial coverage and long time series, which effectively compensates for these deficiencies.

Expectation.Question: What are the reasons for employing machine learning models to estimate crop biomass in agricultural research?
Expectation.Answer: Machine learning models can process large sets of data from field observations and satellite imagery, allowing for accurate biomass estimation. They address the limitations of traditional methods by providing efficient, repeatable, and scalable approaches to estimate crop biomass over large areas.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges faced in data collection for regional crop biomass estimation, particularly regarding the integration of satellite remote sensing and ground observation data?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of satellite remote sensing with ground observation data presents challenges such as ensuring temporal and spatial alignment, data preprocessing, and model calibration. Additionally, the sparse nature of ground data can limit the comprehensive understanding of larger scales, which necessitates careful selection of sample sites and plots. However, remote sensing offers valuable high spatial coverage and long time series data, which helps overcome some limitations of traditional methods.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how field measurements can effectively capture regional crop biomass variations over different growth stages.
Assertion.Answer: Traditional field measurements involve destructive sampling, laboratory drying, and weighing, which are accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming. They are limited in spatial coverage, making it difficult to understand regional variations. Remote sensing, such as MODIS reflectance data, offers a broader spatial and temporal perspective, complementing ground measurements.

Assertion.Question: I can't grasp why machine learning models are preferred for estimating crop biomass over traditional methods.
Assertion.Answer: Machine learning models like RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost are preferred because they can process large datasets from remote sensing sources, offering a more efficient and scalable approach to biomass estimation. These models can integrate diverse datasets, improve prediction accuracy, and overcome the limitations of labor-intensive traditional methods.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure how digital photography can be used to measure vegetation coverage accurately.
Assertion.Answer: Digital photography, used for observing vegetation coverage, involves capturing images that can be analyzed to quantify plant cover percentages. This method provides a non-destructive, rapid assessment tool that complements traditional techniques, allowing for frequent and consistent monitoring of vegetation changes over time.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the effectiveness of machine learning algorithms in estimating crop biomass using ground observation data and remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: The effectiveness of machine learning algorithms in estimating crop biomass was demonstrated using field observation data and MODIS reflectance data. Four algorithms, namely random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), artificial neural network (ANN), and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) were used. The XGBoost model performed the best with an R2 of 0.78, RMSE of 2.86 t/ha, and MAE of 1.86 t/ha, while the RF model had comparable performance with an R2 of 0.77, RMSE of 2.91 t/ha, and MAE of 1.91 t/ha.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges associated with traditional methods of crop biomass estimation and how remote sensing addresses these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Traditional crop biomass estimation methods are labor-intensive, time-consuming, and limited in spatial coverage, making it difficult to achieve regional or larger-scale understanding. Remote sensing addresses these challenges by providing repeatable monitoring, high spatial coverage, and long time series data on vegetation parameters, effectively compensating for the deficiencies of traditional methods.
